text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 9.2.2, Physical Fitness Program.

Internal Controls are the program manual’s policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the: a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated, and key terms are deﬁned; and b. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. (
) To conform to the new Internal Controls standards: a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s: mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agents assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
, Acronym, is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Physical Fitness Program). c. Subsection
, title changed to Authority, and informs of the legal authorities for the program manual (Physical Fitness Program). (

has been updated throughout to cover the current guidelines and procedures in to the Physical Fitness Program. (

9.2.2.1 through 9.2.2.2 reﬂect the IRS requirement that IR manuals address Internal (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and of Internal Controls memo dated September 14, 2016. Internal Controls are the manual’s policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the:
Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated, and key terms are deﬁned; and Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations.
a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s: mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agents assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
, Acronym, is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Physical Fitness Program). c. Subsection
, title changed to Authority, and informs of the legal authorities for the program manual (Physical Fitness Program).

) Special agents are authorized to drive a government vehicle during official hours, to a ﬁtness facility to participate in the PFP (see IRM
(Directive - No.

) Special agents are authorized to use the government-owned vehicle during core-hours on a scheduled workday, provided they go directly from their station to the workout facility/area and then return to the workstation, work- related event, or to their residence. (

) Special agents are allowed to use a government-owned vehicle to drive to a workout facility before or after a scheduled workday as an extension of the core-hour day. This is allowed provided the special agent goes directly from his/her residence to the workout facility/area and then to the workstation (mornings) or directly from the workstation to the workout facility/area and to his/her residence or back to the workstation (evenings). Note: Questions regarding the reasonableness of the distance between the workout facility/area and residence or workstation should be addressed to local management for clariﬁcation. (
) Special agents are not allowed to use GOVs on weekends, holidays or while on leave to drive to a workout facility/area. (
) Special agents medically cleared to participate in PFP are authorized up to

hours per calendar week (Sunday-Saturday) of work time to engage in approved ﬁtness activities. The following guidelines apply: a. There is no accumulation of unused clock-time hours. (Hours cannot carried over from week to week). b. Fitness activities cannot be claimed as hours of work on full days of leave. c. Agents may not receive compensatory time in lieu of overtime, satory time for travel, compensatory time for religious observance, nor regularly scheduled overtime for physical ﬁtness activities. Agents may charge the time to LEAP. d. No more than
and
hours of exercise time can be charged to a workday unless authorized by the SAC. (

) Special agents working a part-time schedule are authorized to engage in approved PFP activities and to record the exercise time as duty hours. The following formula will be used to calculate allowable official time chargeable PFP: (Part-time hours/
) X

) Each participant who uses duty hours for ﬁtness activities will maintain a ﬁtness activity log and record the ﬁtness activity, date, time, and duration of official and personal ﬁtness time. Participants will ﬁle the log within
of the end of each month on a monthly basis. (
) Field/HQ Offices will maintain these activity logs per CI’s TIMS
policy. (

) For purposes of coverage under the Federal Employees Compensation Act, the Department of Labor only recognizes physical ﬁtness activities by the employing agency. When examining claims under FECA, the DOL compare the activity/activities on which the claim is based against the approved activity list to determine whether the claim may be covered under FECA. The DOL does not establish an approved list of activities for each ernmental agency; instead, the DOL allows each individual governmental agency to establish its own list of approved activities for its employees. (

) Approved activities are those that address one or more of the following areas of ﬁtness, which are essential to the safe performance of law ment duties: a. aerobic/cardiovascular endurance b. strength training c. ﬂexibility (

) The following activities are authorized as ﬁtness activities for PFP: a. brisk walking b. running/jogging c. cycling d. cross-country skiing e. stair climbing f. rowing g. the use of ﬁtness equipment related to approved ﬁtness activities as treadmills, stationary bikes, elliptical, rowing and stair-climbing machines) h. swimming i. rope-skipping j. skating (rollerblading and ice skating) k. aerobic/cardiovascular exercises l. strength/resistance exercises (such as weight training, including the use free weights, calisthenics, etc.) m. stretching and ﬂexibility exercises (such as yoga) n. racquet sports (such as racquetball, singles tennis etc.) (
) The following activities are not authorized as ﬁtness activities for PFP: a. Activities performed longer than

hours - Due to a higher likelihood injury when participating in activities for an extended period, agents not permitted to charge as official PFP time, any portion of an PFP activity that is performed for longer than
hours (e.g. the ﬁrst hours of a

-hour weekend bike ride would not be authorized as part the PFP for FECA purposes). A SAC/Director may grant the rare exception to this rule in advance and in writing for an agency event (e.g. law enforcement torch run) where official time will be used participate in the event. Internal Revenue Manual

For purposes of coverage under the Federal Employees Compensation Act, the Department of Labor only recognizes physical ﬁtness activities authorized by the employing agency. When examining claims under FECA, the DOL will compare the activity/activities on which the claim is based against the approved activity list to determine whether the claim may be covered under FECA. The DOL does not establish an approved list of activities for each gov- ernmental agency; instead, the DOL allows each individual governmental agency to establish its own list of approved activities for its employees.
Approved activities are those that address one or more of the following three areas of ﬁtness, which are essential to the safe performance of law enforce-
The following activities are not authorized as ﬁtness activities for PFP:

b. Recreational Sports – Recreational sports such as bowling, badminton, table tennis, and golf are not authorized PFP activities. c. Competitive Team Sports - Due to a higher rate of physical injury com- petitive team sports (e.g. basketball, football, softball, hockey) are not considered an individualized exercise program and are not authorized PFP activities. d. Extreme Sports/Competitions - Activities/Events characterized as are not authorized. For the purposes of this section, an extreme event is deﬁned as a high intensity, high impact, rigorous activity performed continuously for long periods of time (more than

hours) activities/events involving unconventional obstacles/competitions. activities generally involve a higher risk of physical injury. (e.g. ruck march, triathlon, strongman competition activities, obstacle course racing (e.g. Spartan race, Rugged Maniac, Tough Mudder, Warrior Ninja Warrior). (
) If an agent participates in physical activities that are not included in CI’s approved activity list, any injuries resulting from their participation may not covered by the FECA. (
) The following subsections cover the responsibilities of the PFP coordinator, Management, and the special agent. (
) The role of the PFP coordinator includes providing special agents and man- agement with necessary materials and guidance for the administration and oversight of the program. (

) Each PFP coordinator is required to successfully complete the FLETC- LEFCTP or must have previously completed the Cooper Clinic Physical Coordinator Training Program. While other training programs may also be ceptable, they must be reviewed and approved by NCITA as an acceptable alternative. (

) The PFP Coordinator Responsibilities: a. Notiﬁes management and agents of the date, time, and location of the annual ﬁtness assessments and make-up dates to ensure maximum availability. b. Ensures prior to participation that each employee is cleared to in the PFP by contacting Management. c. Informs management when a special agent fails to attend and/or complete all components of a ﬁtness assessment. d. Ensure annual PFP assessment results are recorded and tracked, on ﬁscal year basis, at the Director/Field Office level. e. Considers safety factors during all aspects of ﬁtness testing and tration to minimize liability and prevent injuries. f. Thoroughly documents all exercise-related accidents or injuries during annual PFP assessment. g. When possible, takes corrective action to prevent future accidents injuries of a similar nature. h. Assist agents who request assistance with the establishment of an vidualized health improvement plan. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
E

The PFP Coordinator Responsibilities: a. Notiﬁes management and agents of the date, time, and location of the annual ﬁtness assessments and make

up dates to ensure maximum availability. b. Ensures prior to participation that each employee is cleared to in the PFP by contacting Management. c. Informs management when a special agent fails to attend and/or complete all components of a ﬁtness assessment. d. Ensure annual PFP assessment results are recorded and tracked, on a ﬁscal year basis, at the Director/Field Office level. e. Considers safety factors during all aspects of ﬁtness testing and tration to minimize liability and prevent injuries. f. Thoroughly documents all exercise

related accidents or injuries during annual PFP assessment. g. When possible, takes corrective action to prevent future accidents and/or injuries of a similar nature. h. Assist agents who request assistance with the establishment of an indi
vidualized health improvement plan.
) The Chief, CI will maintain and support the PFP for all IRS-CI special (

) Each Director and Special Agent in Charge will be responsible for the execution and oversight of CI’s PFP for all agents in his/her office as follows: a. Appoint one or more physical ﬁtness coordinators. b. Ensure physical ﬁtness logs/activities are tracked according to estab- lished guidelines. c. Review ﬁtness logs of participants, at least once a quarter, for ness, adherence to approved program activities. d. Assure all agents comply with CI Directive No.

and participate in/ complete all annual physical ﬁtness assessment activities. e. Ensure annual PFP assessment results are recorded and tracked, on a ﬁscal year basis, at the Director/Field Office level. f. Ensure agents do not claim more than
hours of PFP time per week (Sunday-Saturday). (

) Managers will discuss with special agents, as situations arise, when official duties will pre-empt approved ﬁtness program time/activities. These may include scheduled work assignments, illness, injury, or family emergen- cies. (

) Upon notiﬁcation of an injury, Management will review the facts and circum- stances, contact CI’s Medical Program MPA to discuss whether the claim involves an approved PFP activity, ensure the appropriate worker tion forms are timely ﬁled, and consult with their servicing Labor/Employee Relations Specialist, as needed, to determine the appropriate action (e.g., temporary restricted duty (TRD). (
) Special agent responsibilities: a. Timely completion their annual medical screening per CI’s Medical and participating in and completing all events (e.g. complete the entire

-mile run) of the required annual PFP Assessment. b. Self-report any changes in his/her medical or physical condition that affect participation in the PFP per CI’s Medical Policy. c. Ensure that only authorized PFP activities are performed utilizing PFP time. d. Ensure that monthly ﬁtness logs are maintained and submitted as directed within

working days of the end of each month. e. Participates in authorized PFP activities in a safe manner (e.g. Wear a helmet while bicycling). f. Ensures official time devoted to PFP activities does not negatively on official duties. g. Promptly notiﬁes management of injuries sustained during approved activities (during official and non-official duty hours) and timely all necessary worker compensation forms.
Each Director and Special Agent in Charge will be responsible for the execution and oversight of CI’s PFP for all agents in his/her office as follows:
a. Timely completion their annual medical screening per CI’s Medical and participating in and completing all events (e.g. complete the

-mile run) of the required annual PFP Assessment. b. Self-report any changes in his/her medical or physical condition that affect participation in the PFP per CI’s Medical Policy. c. Ensure that only authorized PFP activities are performed utilizing PFP time. d. Ensure that monthly ﬁtness logs are maintained and submitted as directed within

working days of the end of each month. e. Participates in authorized PFP activities in a safe manner (e.g. Wear helmet while bicycling). f. Ensures official time devoted to PFP activities does not negatively on official duties. g. Promptly notiﬁes management of injuries sustained during approved activities (during official and non-official duty hours) and timely all necessary worker compensation forms.
